articles.headline: Low Oil Prices Pose Threat to Texas Fracking Bonanza
articles.snippet: The technology that unlocked the oil in shale fields produced a boom to Karnes County, Tex., but the economy there is cooling fast.
articles.abstract: The technology that unlocked the oil in shale fields produced a boom to Karnes County, Tex., but the economy there is cooling fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARNES CITY, Tex. — No place in Texas produces more oil than Karnes County, but suddenly the roaring economy here is cooling fast, chilled by the plunging price of crude.

articles.headline: Young Mississippi Couple Linked to ISIS, Perplexing All
articles.snippet: The arrests of a young couple suspected of trying to travel from Mississippi to Syria to join the Islamic State have confounded their friends and neighbors.
articles.abstract: The arrests of a young couple suspected of trying to travel from Mississippi to Syria to join the Islamic State have confounded their friends and neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: STARKVILLE, Miss. — She was a cheerleader, an honor student, the daughter of a police officer and a member of the high school homecoming court who wanted to be a doctor.

articles.headline: Offbeat Ways to Make Travel Affordable
articles.snippet: There are many ways for older Americans to travel for less, such as home exchanges, volunteering or teaching a course on a cruise ship.
articles.abstract: There are many ways for older Americans to travel for less, such as home exchanges, volunteering or teaching a course on a cruise ship.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Marie Koski of Springfield, Mass., was in Tuscany, cleaning pottery and bronze items that were more than 2,000 years old, she knew she was on the right trip for the right price.

articles.headline: Hollywood Uses Bigger Screens to Tell Sophisticated Stories
articles.snippet: Large-screen and 3-D formats, usually reserved for action blockbusters aimed at younger audiences, are now being employed for the kind of movies shown at film festivals.
articles.abstract: Large-screen and 3-D formats, usually reserved for action blockbusters aimed at younger audiences, are now being employed for the kind of movies shown at film festivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the literal sense, it is going to be a spectacular film season.

articles.headline: Airbnb Horror Story Points to Need for Precautions
articles.snippet: Travelers must protect themselves by investigating company policies and taking steps to ensure their own security.
articles.abstract: Travelers must protect themselves by investigating company policies and taking steps to ensure their own security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in the evening of July 4, Micaela Giles’s mobile phone started sounding alerts, and a series of messages straight out of a horror movie began scrolling down her screen.

articles.headline: Betting on a Smooth Ride, Investors Flock to Tesla
articles.snippet: The company seems to embody many of a typical Wall Street investor’s desires: disruptive technology, larger-than-life founders and dazzling growth projections.
articles.abstract: The company seems to embody many of a typical Wall Street investor’s desires: disruptive technology, larger-than-life founders and dazzling growth projections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors has seemingly defied the law of financial gravity on Wall Street ever since the company began proving that electric cars could be sporty, powerful and trendy — not just green.

articles.headline: Edward Thomas, Policing Pioneer Who Wore a Burden Stoically, Dies at 95
articles.snippet: The first African-American to build a career with the Houston Police Department could not walk through the front door when he reported for work in 1948. Now Police Headquarters is named for him.
articles.abstract: The first African-American to build a career with the Houston Police Department could not walk through the front door when he reported for work in 1948. Now Police Headquarters is named for him.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Edward Thomas joined the Houston Police Department in 1948, he could not report for work through the front door.

articles.headline: Inside Amazon: Wrestling Big Ideas in a Bruising Workplace
articles.snippet: The company is conducting an experiment in how far it can push white-collar workers to get them to achieve its ever-expanding ambitions.
articles.abstract: The company is conducting an experiment in how far it can push white-collar workers to get them to achieve its ever-expanding ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — On Monday mornings, fresh recruits line up for an orientation intended to catapult them into Amazon’s singular way of working.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: G.O.P. Is Vague on Using Power Abroad
articles.snippet: Finding any consensus on how the Republican candidates would exercise American power differently from President Obama, much less define an alternative foreign policy, gets a bit messy.
articles.abstract: Finding any consensus on how the Republican candidates would exercise American power differently from President Obama, much less define an alternative foreign policy, gets a bit messy.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the diverse group of candidates competing for the Republican presidential nomination agree on one thing when describing how they would engage with the world if they made it to the White House, it is this: If only the United States were stronger, and more feared, the country would not feel threatened by the Islamic State, manipulated by Iran or challenged by a rising China.

articles.headline: Locked in Solitary at 14: Adult Jails Isolate Youths Despite Risk
articles.snippet: A Mississippi 16-year-old is emblematic of juveniles across the nation, charged as adults, who endure protective isolation that experts say can lead to depression and other mental health problems.
articles.abstract: A Mississippi 16-year-old is emblematic of juveniles across the nation, charged as adults, who endure protective isolation that experts say can lead to depression and other mental health problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — The prisoner spent a fitful August night trying to tune out the howls and moans of inmates in adjoining cells. He did not stir from his thin sleep mat until well after 1 p.m. A breakfast of cold grits waited in a slot in the reinforced steel door.

articles.headline: AT&T Helped U.S. Spy on Internet on a Vast Scale
articles.snippet: Newly disclosed N.S.A. documents show that the agency gained access to billions of emails through a “highly collaborative” relationship with AT&T.
articles.abstract: Newly disclosed N.S.A. documents show that the agency gained access to billions of emails through a “highly collaborative” relationship with AT&T.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency’s ability to spy on vast quantities of Internet traffic passing through the United States has relied on its extraordinary, decades-long partnership with a single company: the telecom giant AT&T.
articles.byline: By Julia Angwin, Charlie Savage, Jeff Larson, Henrik Moltke, Laura Poitras and James Risen

articles.headline: A Fashion Trailblazer’s Stylish Leap From Touch to Touch Screen
articles.snippet: In a business that relies on personal interaction with people and clothes, MatchesFashion.com, a high-end retailer in Britain, is making the jump to e-commerce.
articles.abstract: In a business that relies on personal interaction with people and clothes, MatchesFashion.com, a high-end retailer in Britain, is making the jump to e-commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a small house in South London, five executives of the high-end fashion retailer MatchesFashion.com sat around an oval conference table, discussing a coming event. From outside, the house looked like any sweet two-story London cottage, with a cobblestone courtyard and small balcony, but inside, it was all white and open plan — more Silicon Valley than Staffordshire.

articles.headline: The Greek Debt Deal’s Missing Piece
articles.snippet: The latest bailout agreement between Greece and its European creditors will go forward without cash from one crucial lender: the International Monetary Fund.
articles.abstract: The latest bailout agreement between Greece and its European creditors will go forward without cash from one crucial lender: the International Monetary Fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: At long last, European creditor nations and Greece have reached an agreement on a third bailout in five years.

articles.headline: ‘Key & Peele’ Ends While Nation Could Still Use a Laugh
articles.snippet: How will television viewers hungry for sketches about racial injustice fill the gap after Comedy Central’s of-the-moment series ends its run?
articles.abstract: How will television viewers hungry for sketches about racial injustice fill the gap after Comedy Central’s of-the-moment series ends its run?
articles.lead_paragraph: The scene is a hauntingly familiar one: A white police officer stalks an unarmed black man in a dark alley and slams the man’s head into the open door of his patrol car.

articles.headline: Disney Bulks Up Theme Parks, as Universal Gains Ground
articles.snippet: After Disney’s aggressive overseas investment — which gave Universal an opening in the United States — Disney announced expensive plans for “Star Wars”-themed expansions at its California and Florida resorts.
articles.abstract: After Disney’s aggressive overseas investment — which gave Universal an opening in the United States — Disney announced expensive plans for “Star Wars”-themed expansions at its California and Florida resorts.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The empire is striking back.

articles.headline: Blending Tech Workers and Locals in San Francisco’s Troubled Mid-Market
articles.snippet: Tech giants like Twitter and Spotify have descended on one of the poorest neighborhoods in the Bay Area, bringing prosperity for some and upheaval for others.
articles.abstract: Tech giants like Twitter and Spotify have descended on one of the poorest neighborhoods in the Bay Area, bringing prosperity for some and upheaval for others.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last spring, Carlo Gascon’s organization took a chance on this city’s extraordinary technology boom, paying $1.4 million to turn a rundown single-family structure in the troubled Mid-Market area into its headquarters.

articles.headline: Julian Bond, Charismatic Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 75
articles.snippet: Mr. Bond was also a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a former chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bond was also a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a former chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julian Bond, a charismatic figure of the 1960s civil rights movement, a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a lifelong champion of equal rights, notably as chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., died on Saturday night in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. He was 75.

articles.headline: Exclusion of Blacks From Juries Raises Renewed Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A study in Louisiana has found that prosecutors used peremptory challenges three times as often to strike black potential jurors as others during the last decade.
articles.abstract: A study in Louisiana has found that prosecutors used peremptory challenges three times as often to strike black potential jurors as others during the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHREVEPORT, La. — Here are some reasons prosecutors have offered for excluding blacks from juries: They were young or old, single or divorced, religious or not, failed to make eye contact, lived in a poor part of town, had served in the military, had a hyphenated last name, displayed bad posture, were sullen, disrespectful or talkative, had long hair, wore a beard.

articles.headline: Obama Administration Warns Beijing About Covert Agents Operating in U.S.
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has warned Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates to return home immediately, according to American officials.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has warned Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates to return home immediately, according to American officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has delivered a warning to Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates — some wanted in China on charges of corruption — to return home immediately, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Dan Levin

articles.headline: With High-Profile Help, Obama Plots Life After Presidency
articles.snippet: President Obama’s preparations for an estimated $1 billion effort, including a library and global foundation, are showing the same fierce discipline he displayed in winning office.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s preparations for an estimated $1 billion effort, including a library and global foundation, are showing the same fierce discipline he displayed in winning office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dinner in the private upstairs dining room of the White House went so late that Reid Hoffman, the LinkedIn billionaire, finally suggested around midnight that President Obama might like to go to bed.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: Racial Wealth Gap Persists Despite Degree, Study Says
articles.snippet: New research shakes the long-held belief that higher education clears a path to financial equality for blacks and Hispanics, and contends that the problem is deeply rooted and persistent.
articles.abstract: New research shakes the long-held belief that higher education clears a path to financial equality for blacks and Hispanics, and contends that the problem is deeply rooted and persistent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even with tuition shooting up, the payoff from a college degree remains strong, lifting lifelong earnings and protecting many graduates like a Teflon coating against the worst effects of economic downturns.

articles.headline: Japan Says Its Economy Contracted in Second Quarter
articles.snippet: The size of the contraction was roughly in line with the expectations of private-sector economists, but the slowdown is nonetheless a setback for the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
articles.abstract: The size of the contraction was roughly in line with the expectations of private-sector economists, but the slowdown is nonetheless a setback for the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Burdened by weaker consumer spending and exports, Japan’s economy contracted in the second quarter, government data showed on Monday, the first such setback since a short but painful recession last year.

articles.headline: Where Clicks Reign, Audience Is King
articles.snippet: As more readers move toward online social networks, and as publishers desperately seek scale to bring in revenue, many have deplored a race toward repetitive journalism.
articles.abstract: As more readers move toward online social networks, and as publishers desperately seek scale to bring in revenue, many have deplored a race toward repetitive journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last month, a lion known as Cecil was killed by a hunter near Hwange National Park in Zimbabwe.

articles.headline: Data-Crunching Is Coming to Help Your Boss Manage Your Time
articles.snippet: Employers of all types are using a wide range of technological tools to monitor workers’ efforts and motivate them.
articles.abstract: Employers of all types are using a wide range of technological tools to monitor workers’ efforts and motivate them.
articles.lead_paragraph: You might be at work, but that hardly means you are working.

articles.headline: The Local Airport, by Any Other Name
articles.snippet: A growing number of smaller airports coping with declining traffic are changing their names as airline consolidation funnels fliers to major hubs.
articles.abstract: A growing number of smaller airports coping with declining traffic are changing their names as airline consolidation funnels fliers to major hubs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judging by his résumé alone, Albert Gallatin would seem a fine choice to have an important local landmark in Montana, like an airport, named after him.

articles.headline: Jihad and Girl Power: How ISIS Lured 3 London Girls
articles.snippet: An online culture that blends youthful rebellion with radical religiosity helped draw popular, high-achieving friends to Syria.
articles.abstract: An online culture that blends youthful rebellion with radical religiosity helped draw popular, high-achieving friends to Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The night before Khadiza Sultana left for Syria she was dancing in her teenage bedroom. It was a Monday during the February school vacation. Her niece and close friend, at 13 only three years younger than Khadiza, had come for a sleepover. The two girls wore matching pajamas and giggled as they gyrated in unison to the beat.

articles.headline: Artifacts from Crimean Museums Are Held Hostage by Politics
articles.snippet: Hundreds of treasures on loan in Amsterdam from four Crimean museums remain in storage awaiting a court decision about their future.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of treasures on loan in Amsterdam from four Crimean museums remain in storage awaiting a court decision about their future.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Nearly a year after the popular exhibition “Crimea: Gold and Secrets From the Black Sea” wrapped up at the Allard Pierson Museum here, 565 rare treasures on loan from four Crimean museums remain in boxes in a storage facility, awaiting a court decision about where they should be shipped.

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos and Amazon Employees Join Debate Over Its Culture
articles.snippet: The company’s chief told employees that he didn’t recognize the “soulless, dystopian workplace” that he said was depicted in a New York Times article.
articles.abstract: The company’s chief told employees that he didn’t recognize the “soulless, dystopian workplace” that he said was depicted in a New York Times article.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 20 years, Amazon has reveled in its toughness. “Work hard” are the first two words of a company motto. An oft-repeated line from Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive, calls the company culture “friendly and intense, but if push comes to shove we’ll settle for intense.”
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Liberty Interactive Agrees to Buy Zulily for $2.4 Billion
articles.snippet: The transaction, is expected to bolster Liberty’s QVC Group business, but it also is only the latest instance of a company going public, then selling itself shortly afterward.
articles.abstract: The transaction, is expected to bolster Liberty’s QVC Group business, but it also is only the latest instance of a company going public, then selling itself shortly afterward.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Zulily, the flash-sales site for mothers, began life as a publicly traded company in fall 2013, it found plenty of favor among investors, who pushed its stock up 70 percent on its first trading day.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: China Turned to Risky Devaluation as Export Machine Stalled
articles.snippet: A statement by China’s top leadership showed its willingness to make trade-offs to reinvigorate exports as a troubled economy risks setting off political turmoil.
articles.abstract: A statement by China’s top leadership showed its willingness to make trade-offs to reinvigorate exports as a troubled economy risks setting off political turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Prime Minister Li Keqiang convened the Chinese cabinet last month, the troubled economy was the main topic on the agenda.
